name: sodium tetrahydridoborate production, Brown-Schlesinger process | sodium methoxide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/1069/documentation

This dataset represents the Brown-Schlesinger process.The functional unit is 1 kg trimethyl borate. The system includes the process with consumption of raw materials, energy, infrastructure, and land use, as well as the generation of emissions to air and water. It also includes transportation of the raw materials. Transient or unstable operations like starting-up or shutting-down, are not included, but the production during stable operation conditions. Storage and transportation of the final product are also not included. It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area. The emissions into water are assumed to be emitted into rivers. Within the Brown-Schlesinger process, sodium tetrahydroborate and sodium methoxide are derived as co-product, so it is a multi output process. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and methyl borate (B(OCH3)) at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the Brown-Schlesinger process, including materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for the world..
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The Brown-Schlesinger process is one of the most important production processes for sodium tetrahydroborate.In the Brown-Schlesinger-Process methyl borate is added to hydrogenated sodium in mineral oil: ;4 Na + 2 H2 +B(OCH3)3  → NaBH4 + 3 NaOCH3;Separation of the sodium methoxide from NaBH4 was accomplished by such methods as extraction with amines, and extraction with water followed by a counterextraction with a solvent, such as 2-aminopropane.;The sodium and hydrogen for the Brown-Schlesinger process are produced by an electrolysis of NaOH. ;2 NaOH → 2 Na + O2 + H2;The overall equation for the process:;4 NaOH + B(OCH3)3 → NaBH4 + 3 NaOCH3 + O2;;Baudis, U., Fichte, R.: Boron and Boron Alloys. Published online: 2000. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/emrw/9783527306732/home
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Energy consumptions and emissions are estimated. Infrastructure and transports are calculated with standard values.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The remaining amount of unreacted sodium hydroxide and trimethyl borate is assumed to leave the production process with the waste water. Further it was assumed that this wastewater is treated in a internal wastewater plant. The removal efficiency for trimethyl borate is assumed with 90%.

Estimation. The remaining amount of unreacted sodium hydroxide and trimethyl borate is assumed to leave the production process with the waste water. Further it was assumed that this wastewater is treated in a internal wastewater plant. The removal efficiency for trimethyl borate is assumed with 90%.

Estimation. The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of trimethyl borate in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

Estimation. The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of trimethyl borate in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

EcoSpold01Location=RER
Stoichiometric calculation. It is calculated with a yield of 95 %.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. This data was taken from a large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. The values for the energy consumption per kg of product of this plant (3.2 MJ kg-1) were used as approximation for the energy consumption of the Brown-Schlesinger process. This total energy demand contains a split of 50% natural gas, 38% electricity and 12% steam from external energy sources. For this dataset all energy used for heat or steam was assumed to be natural gas.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of trimethyl borate in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.

EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
Estimation. This data was taken from a large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. The values for the energy consumption per kg of product of this plant (3.2 MJ kg-1) were used as approximation for the energy consumption of the Brown-Schlesinger process. This total energy demand contains a split of 50% natural gas, 38% electricity and 12% steam from external energy sources. For this dataset all energy used for heat or steam was assumed to be natural gas. For the electricity, a reference of sodium hydroxide electrolysis reports an electricity consumption of 10 kWh per kg sodium is taken into account.

Further references:

Baudis, U., Fichte, R.: Boron and Boron Alloys. Published online: 2000. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/emrw/9783527306732/home

exchanges.description:
Estimation. This data was estimated with data from an large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. This value was used in this inventory as approximation for the cooling water consumption of the chlorosilane amination.

Estimation. This data was estimated with data from an large chemical plant site in Germany producing 2.05 Mt a-1 (intermediates included) of different chemicals. This value was used in this inventory as approximation for the cooling water consumption of the chlorosilane amination.

Estimation. The remaining amount of unreacted sodium hydroxide and trimethyl borate is assumed to leave the production process with the waste water. Further it was assumed that this wastewater is treated in a internal wastewater plant. The removal efficiency for trimethyl borate is assumed with 90%. The trimethyl borate is calculated as boron emission.

Estimation. The values for COD, BOD, TOC, and DOC used in this inventory are calculated from the amount of trimethyl borate in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD. For the calculation of the values for BOD and DOC the worst case scenario BOD = COD and TOC = DOC is used.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.
Calculated value based on literature values and expert opinion. See comments in the parametres' comment field.

Estimation. This module assumes a built area of about 4.2 ha, an average output of 50'000 t/a, and plant life of fifty years.
